questions.neutral: Feels cooler down here, doesn't it?

hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, it's cooler. Good place to think.
I fold some origami to pass time. Quiet hobby, nothing much.
Kind of tricky lately, with all the noise from those juries.
Doesn’t matter, I just keep it simple.
Yeah. I like it quieter here.
I fold origami — keeps my hands steady. Just paper and patterns.
Lately, neighbors notice everything. Harder to focus when people are on edge.
After the jury broadcasts, even my hobby feels... visible.
I keep my projects small, easy to put away.
It does. Helps me clear my head.
I spend time folding origami, precise shapes — cranes, tessellations, modular stars.
Used to be something private, helps me steady my thoughts.
The last week, everyone's talking about the citizen juries. Hard to ignore.
Someone asked me for a protest piece the other day, odd feeling.
Hobbies change when the city's watching.
Feels good to step out of recycled air.
I usually unwind folding complex origami — I know, bit old-fashioned.
It keeps my mind sharp when everything else seems tangled.
But since those jury livestreams started, even the laundry room isn’t quiet.
A neighbor saw me folding — now my tessellations ended up in their protest mural.
Never thought paper folds could end up tied to BCI politics.
It’s strange seeing something personal exposed like that.
Cooler, yes. Almost peaceful.
Origami's my habit — not just cranes, but intricate geometric designs, even corrugation patterns.
I work on them late, sometimes at work if the system's up.
Since the jury leaks and BCI protests, my building’s tense. Folding’s no longer just an escape.
Last week, my hobby got co-opted for protest — neighbors used my models in their mural.
Part of me worries about what linking my work to that might mean.
I never meant for folding to make a statement. Used to keep me hidden, not exposed.
Feels like the city tries to fold us into its patterns too.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Keeps my mind steady when things outside aren't.
Just fold at home usually. Quiet evenings.
People talk too much about hobbies lately.
With all that's happening, best to keep to myself.
Guess everyone's careful now.
Origami helps. Simple, methodical.
Started folding more since the BCI leaks, actually.
Quiet hobby. Not much to explain.
Saw my neighbor watching the hearings while I folded last night.
Strange how folding cranes now feels like a statement.
Even paper can draw the wrong attention lately.
Yeah, origami's still my way to focus.
I fold models by memory now, safer than following guides online.
Was working on a tessellation during that last jury livestream.
Neighbors noticed, started asking about my patterns.
Noise outside distracts me, but folding settles my thoughts.
Hard to keep things private. Even paper shapes get noticed these days.
Feels like every little thing is under a lens since the leaks.
Origami's always felt like a safe pattern in the chaos.
Lately, the hearing streams made it hard to concentrate. I can't tune them out.
Last week, someone asked me to fold protest art for that BCI mural.
I hesitated, didn't want my name on anything public, but said yes anyway.
The blocks are tense. People look at even my hobby sideways now.
I've started folding at awkward hours. Less risk of being asked to 'contribute.'
Strange, right? Paper feels more political than ever.
Not sure if it's safe, but I still fold. It's habit by now.
Origami's my anchor. My mother taught me after my father vanished in early BCI trials.
It used to just be mine. Now others see it as a statement.
Last week during the jury stream, neighbors came by, asked for folded pieces for a protest mural.
They said, 'Your hands know the right patterns for this.' I wasn't sure how to answer.
All these new hearings blur lines. Even a paper dragon on my windowsill gets questions.
I started folding camouflage models to blend in, not stand out.
Feels like the city is folding itself, patterns shifting with every leak.
I keep my special models hidden now, just in case. Even my hobby got politicized.
Still, I can't stop. It's the only thing that makes the noise manageable.
